head.supplied: 14/11/90. ¶ It is very pleasing to me, dear Dr Britton, that you think so well of the Census of Austral. plants; ¶ B89.12.03. ¶ with this mail I beg to send you the Key to the system of Vict, pl., ¶ ...

p.seg: Nathaniel Lord Britton Records, Archives of the New York Botanical Garden, New York.
It is very pleasing to me, dear Dr Britton, that you think so well of the Census of Austral. plants;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3346in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3346in; font-size: 9pt;

p.seg: with this mail I beg to send you the Key to the system of Vict, pl.,

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3346in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3346in; font-size: 9pt;

p.seg: in which I have likewise employed the simplified Juss—D.C. system, and also reduced the phytographic terms.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3346in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3346in; font-size: 9pt;
p.seg: See Maroske (2006) for an analysis of M's longstanding rationale for simplifying the
Jussieu-De Candolle system to make it more 'natural'; for 'reduction in phytographic terms', see B89.05.04.
It is very kind of you to send me what you have of RBr's Austral. specimens. Though I have many authentic specimens of his,

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3346in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3346in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: Joseph Hooker had sent five cases of specimens collected by Robert Brown (1773-1858) to M, selected from those received by Kew from the British Museum; see M to J. Hooker, 29 May 1882.

p.seg: we can never have too much from his hands. I will make a good return sending of Austral specimens named. If I can be of any utility to you here, then command unhesitatingly my services.
